section: Client acknowledges and agrees that any due dates set forth in the Scope of Work are not subject to any delay. <*$p$*>
explanation: This statement creates a contradiction when considered against the possibility of Change Orders, Client-submitted content delays, or other unforeseen issues. While the contract states deadlines are not subject to delay, section 1(a) outlines that changes to the scope of work may incur additional work, which would inherently cause a delay. Similarly, 1(c) outlines that the content should be provided in a certain format, which will inherently cause a delay. Such delays are not accounted for in the agreement, creating uncertainty in enforcing the deadlines.

section: Any email or telephone correspondence received after normal business hours will be processed the following business day. Client may be asked to pay an additional surcharge for any services requiring work to be performed outside of normal business hours by reason of a rush deadline requested by Client or as a result of Client's failure to meet scheduled times for delivery and/or review and approval of information, content and materials. <*$p$*>
explanation: The statement that a client 'may be asked' to pay an additional surcharge is ambiguous and lacks specific details about when such a surcharge will be applied. It doesn't clearly define the criteria for determining when a surcharge is mandatory versus discretionary, leading to uncertainty. Because of this uncertainty, there is no clearly defined obligation to the client, especially where the criteria are undefined.

section: Company at its sole discretion may at any time alter or cease providing the Customer Service which it has agreed to provide to Client relating to Client Website pursuant to this Agreement without any liability to Company. <*$p$*>
explanation: This clause presents a contradiction because while the company agrees to provide customer service, it simultaneously reserves the right to unilaterally cease providing that service at any time without incurring liability. This effectively nullifies the initial agreement to provide customer service and creates ambiguity about the company's actual obligations. This makes the initial agreement to provide customer service not binding, as the Company has the power to change its terms at any moment.
